narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The types of scientific data expected to be generated in this project include tabular demographic/clinical data, MRI imaging data (structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS), plus derived measures and documentation (data dictionaries, protocols, README). Estimated data volume will be approximately 220 participants, including multi-modal MRI imaging files. Imaging data will comprise the largest share.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data generated in this project, including demographic/clinical data, MRI imaging data, derived measures, and documentation, will be preserved and shared to facilitate interpretation of the results and potential future research. This decision is justified by the importance of making research findings publicly available and contributing to the advancement of knowledge.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: Metadata, including study protocols, data collection instruments, and README files, will be made accessible to facilitate interpretation of the scientific data.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Not applicable. Specialized tools, software, or code are not needed to access or manipulate shared scientific data.

The following common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata:

* For MRI imaging data, headers will be derived from the Dublin Core standard, with the exception of MRI data, which will be organized and named according to the BIDS (Brain Imaging Data Structure) standard.
* No consensus standards exist for demographic/clinical data.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The primary data repository for data sharing will be the Open Science Framework (OSF), which has been approved by the HEAL initiative as meeting NIH policy for data sharing and management.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: Scientific data will be made available via a persistent unique identifier, enabling efficient searching and retrieval.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the end of the performance period, approximately 2 years from project initiation.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Human research participants have provided consent for broad data sharing, and all applicable factors or data use limitations will be taken into consideration when making the scientific data available.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the human datasets in NeMO (National Mouse Xenograft) is controlled through the NIMH Data Archive Data Access Committee.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: The privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants will be protected through de-identification, Certificates of Confidentiality, and other protective measures.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer:
Compliance with this Plan will be monitored and managed by the Lead PI (Laura Simons) who is responsible for day-to-day oversight of data management activities. Regular meetings with the research team will ensure that all aspects of data sharing are implemented as planned.

This plan is based on NIH's guidelines and policies regarding data management and sharing, specifically:

* NIH's stewardship of human genomic data
* Informed consent under which the data or samples were collected
* Use of repositories such as Open Science Framework (OSF) and NIMH Data Archive (NDA)
* Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

This plan will be regularly reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with NIH's policies and guidelines.
